Objection answered.
It having been observed that Olive Oil which nearly if not 
altogether equals glass in refractive power, is introduced between 
lenses where primary rings are formed, that the colours will 
totally disappear; because in this case the interval between the 
lenses is filled up by a substance equal in refractive power to 
the glass itself: why then it may be asked, should colours 
appear in thin glass plates, when the interval between the 
refracting strata, is occupied by glass itself? 
Answer. The cases are apparently similar but not 
really so; in the case of Newtonian rings being formed 
the rarer medium is interposed between the two denser; 
whereas in thin coloured plates, the denser medium is in-
terposed between the two rarer. in the production of Newton-
ian rings, the refraction is made from glass into Air, 
& the second from Air into glass: but in the production 
of colour in thin plates, the contrary order takes place. when 
the colours of Newtonian rings are destroyed by the introduction 
of Olive Oil between the lenses, the effect is produced by chan-
geing the whole apparatus into one solid mass & therby taking 
away the refracting strata of this glass plates; still those 
strata are in contact with the circumambient Air & also 
within the reach of each others influence; but if thin 
coloured plates are immerged in Olive Oyle, it will be as 
effectual in causing the colours to disappear as by its 
introduction between glass lenses; because in both cases 
the refracting strata are equally destroyed by changeing 
the whole apparatus into one continuous mass. 
Should it still be objected; that admitting the truth of the 
Hypothesis, there is only one step gained; since it still remains 
to be explained how the supposed cause produces its effects.
